paintings.title: The Night Watch
paintings.author: Rembrandt
paintings.description: One of Rembrandt's most famous works, depicting Amsterdam's civic militia.
paintings.history: Painted in 1642, it is renowned for its dramatic use of light and shadow.
paintings.symbolism: Symbolizes vigilance and civic duty.

paintings.title: The Rape of the Sabine Women
paintings.author: Nicolas Poussin
paintings.description: Depicts the legendary episode of the abduction of the Sabine women by the Romans.
paintings.history: Painted in 1637, it explores classical themes and a carefully balanced composition.
paintings.symbolism: Reflects on the founding of Rome and conflicts between cultures.

paintings.title: Judith Slaying Holofernes
paintings.author: Artemisia Gentileschi
paintings.description: An intense depiction of the moment Judith beheads Holofernes.
paintings.history: Gentileschi painted several versions of this subject, emphasizing female strength.
paintings.symbolism: Symbolizes justice and courage in the face of oppression.

paintings.title: Las Meninas
paintings.author: Diego Velázquez
paintings.description: A complex court scene that challenges the viewer's perceptions.
paintings.history: Painted in 1656, it is one of the most analyzed works in Western art history.
paintings.symbolism: Explores themes of reality and illusion in art.

paintings.title: The Calling of Saint Matthew
paintings.author: Caravaggio
paintings.description: Shows the moment Jesus calls Matthew to follow him.
paintings.history: One of Caravaggio's masterpieces, noted for its dramatic use of light.
paintings.symbolism: Represents divine calling and spiritual transformation.

paintings.title: Saint Jerome in Meditation
paintings.author: Caravaggio
paintings.description: Depicts Saint Jerome in a moment of contemplation.
paintings.history: Painted in 1605, it exemplifies Caravaggio's tenebrist style.
paintings.symbolism: Symbolizes penitence and the search for wisdom.

paintings.title: The Triumph of Bacchus
paintings.author: Diego Velázquez
paintings.description: Shows the god Bacchus crowning a soldier with a vine wreath.
paintings.history: Also known as 'The Drunkards', it was painted by Velázquez early in his career.
paintings.symbolism: Explores the duality between the divine and the worldly.

paintings.title: The Ecstasy of Saint Teresa
paintings.author: Gian Lorenzo Bernini
paintings.description: A sculpture that captures Saint Teresa's mystical moment.
paintings.history: Created by Bernini, it is a masterpiece of Baroque sculpture.
paintings.symbolism: Represents spiritual union with the divine.

paintings.title: Susanna and the Elders
paintings.author: Rembrandt
paintings.description: Depicts the biblical story of Susanna being watched by elders.
paintings.history: Painted by Rembrandt, it highlights vulnerability and injustice.
paintings.symbolism: Symbolizes chastity and the injustice faced by women.

paintings.title: Belshazzar's Feast
paintings.author: Rembrandt
paintings.description: Shows King Belshazzar during a banquet interrupted by a divine message.
paintings.history: Rembrandt captured the king's moment of shock and terror.
paintings.symbolism: Reflects on pride and divine judgment.

paintings.title: Liberty Leading the People
paintings.author: Eugène Delacroix
paintings.description: One of the most iconic Romantic works, showing Liberty personified leading the French people in revolution.
paintings.history: Painted in 1830, it became an icon of the French Revolution and the struggle for freedom.
paintings.symbolism: Liberty is depicted as a female figure guiding the revolutionaries to victory.

paintings.title: The Raft of the Medusa
paintings.author: Théodore Géricault
paintings.description: Depicts the dramatic wreck of a French ship, with survivors fighting for their lives on an improvised raft.
paintings.history: Painted in 1819, it is considered one of the most important works of Romanticism, known for its realistic and emotional portrayal.
paintings.symbolism: The scene shows despair and the struggle for survival, reflecting human tragedy.

paintings.title: The Nightmare
paintings.author: Henry Fuseli
paintings.description: A surreal depiction of a nightmare, with a woman lying down as a demon watches over her.
paintings.history: Painted in 1781, it was one of the first works to explore nightmares and the unconscious.
paintings.symbolism: Symbolizes inner fears and the dark forces of the human unconscious.

paintings.title: The Sea of Ice
paintings.author: Caspar David Friedrich
paintings.description: Shows a journey through a frozen, desolate landscape typical of Friedrich's Romantic scenes.
paintings.history: Painted in 1824, it exemplifies Friedrich's unique style focused on vast landscapes and feelings of solitude.
paintings.symbolism: Represents humanity's struggle against nature, and the search for meaning in a vast, mysterious world.

paintings.title: Wanderer above the Sea of Fog
paintings.author: Caspar David Friedrich
paintings.description: Shows a man on a cliff looking out over a mist-covered landscape, capturing nature's sublime beauty.
paintings.history: Created in 1818, it is one of Friedrich's most famous works and symbolizes the relationship between humans and nature.
paintings.symbolism: The wanderer symbolizes humanity's spiritual quest, and nature as a vast, unknowable mystery.

paintings.title: The Death of Sardanapalus
paintings.author: Eugène Delacroix
paintings.description: Depicts the death of the Assyrian king Sardanapalus, who orders the destruction of everything around him before being captured.
paintings.history: Painted in 1827, it showcases Delacroix's ability to portray violence and intense emotion.
paintings.symbolism: Symbolizes the decay of an empire and despair in the face of an inevitable end.

paintings.title: Monk by the Sea
paintings.author: Caspar David Friedrich
paintings.description: A solitary monk gazing at the vast sea, a theme common in many of Friedrich's works.
paintings.history: Created between 1808 and 1810, it conveys feelings of solitude and introspection.
paintings.symbolism: Represents spiritual contemplation and inner searching through observing nature.

paintings.title: Snow Storm
paintings.author: J.M.W. Turner
paintings.description: Depicts a ship battling a fierce snow storm, an example of Turner's mastery of nature's forces.
paintings.history: Painted in 1842, it demonstrates Turner's talent for capturing nature's destructive power.
paintings.symbolism: The storm symbolizes nature's uncontrollable forces and human vulnerability.

paintings.title: Rain, Steam and Speed
paintings.author: J.M.W. Turner
paintings.description: Shows a steam train crossing a bridge, symbolizing progress and the Industrial Revolution.
paintings.history: Painted in 1844, it is among Turner's most representative works, focused on the dynamism of modernity.
paintings.symbolism: Symbolizes the rise of industry and the impact of the Industrial Revolution on society.

paintings.title: The Acrobats
paintings.author: Gustave Doré
paintings.description: Depicts a group of street performers putting on a show, capturing the energy and vitality of the moment.
paintings.history: Painted in 1874, Doré explored themes of marginalized figures and bohemian street life.
paintings.symbolism: Represents freedom of expression and life on society's margins.

paintings.title: Les Demoiselles d'Avignon
paintings.author: Pablo Picasso
paintings.description: One of the earliest Cubist works, depicting five nude women with geometric forms and sharp angles.
paintings.history: Painted in 1907, it is a milestone in the development of Cubism, challenging traditional art conventions.
paintings.symbolism: The deconstruction of human forms represents a new approach to perceiving reality.

paintings.title: Guernica
paintings.author: Pablo Picasso
paintings.description: A monumental painting depicting the bombing of the Basque town of Guernica during the Spanish Civil War.
paintings.history: Created in 1937 in response to the aerial attack on Guernica, it became a powerful symbol against violence and war.
paintings.symbolism: Pain, chaos, and the destruction of war are expressed through distorted, fragmented figures.

paintings.title: The Bottle of Wine
paintings.author: Juan Gris
paintings.description: A Cubist work depicting a wine bottle in a geometric, analytical manner.
paintings.history: Painted in 1913, it is a classic example of Synthetic Cubism, focused on everyday subject matter.
paintings.symbolism: The fragmentation of form reflects Gris's search for a broken-down, analytical representation of reality.

paintings.title: Violin and Candlestick
paintings.author: Georges Braque
paintings.description: A Cubist work that deconstructs the form of a violin and a candlestick, representing everyday objects in an abstract way.
paintings.history: Created in 1910, it is among the early works of Analytical Cubism, focused on breaking down form.
paintings.symbolism: The fragmentation of objects reflects the idea of depicting reality from multiple perspectives.

paintings.title: Woman with a Mandolin
paintings.author: Georges Braque
paintings.description: A female figure playing a mandolin, rendered in geometric forms characteristic of Cubism.
paintings.history: Painted in 1910, it explores the deconstruction of the human figure and the integration of music and visual art.
paintings.symbolism: The figure and instrument are presented abstractly, symbolizing the fusion of art and sound.

paintings.title: Portrait of Pablo Picasso
paintings.author: Juan Gris
paintings.description: A Cubist portrait of Pablo Picasso using geometric forms and a restrained color palette.
paintings.history: Painted in 1912, it is one of the best-known examples of Synthetic Cubism developed by Gris.
paintings.symbolism: Portraying Picasso through fragmented forms and multiple perspectives reflects the artist's multifaceted character.

paintings.title: The Poet
paintings.author: Pablo Picasso
paintings.description: A Cubist work portraying a poet, with fragmented elements and multiple perspectives on the face and surrounding objects.
paintings.history: Created in 1911, it reflects the use of geometric forms and the attempt to represent the subject in a non-linear way.
paintings.symbolism: The fusion of the poet with the surrounding environment symbolizes the intimate relationship between the artist and the work.

paintings.title: The Reader
paintings.author: Fernand Léger
paintings.description: A portrait of a man reading, with simplified forms and vivid colors characteristic of Léger's style.
paintings.history: Painted in 1924, it explores bold forms and contrasting colors, moving away from more analytical Cubism.
paintings.symbolism: The emphasis on simple forms and vibrant color symbolizes the search for new artistic expression.

paintings.title: Still Life with Chair Caning
paintings.author: Pablo Picasso
paintings.description: One of the first Cubist works to combine collage with painting, depicting chair caning and other objects.
paintings.history: Created in 1912, it marks the transition from Analytical Cubism to Synthetic Cubism through the use of collage elements.
paintings.symbolism: Combining three-dimensional and two-dimensional elements symbolizes an attempt to bring art closer to physical reality.

paintings.title: The City
paintings.author: Fernand Léger
paintings.description: A Cubist work portraying urban life and modernity, with geometric forms and a palette of primary colors.
paintings.history: Painted in 1919, it reflects the impact of modern, industrial life on post-war art.
paintings.symbolism: Geometric forms and primary colors symbolize the rationalization and mechanization of urban life.

paintings.title: Impression, Sunrise
paintings.author: Claude Monet
paintings.description: Famous for giving the Impressionist movement its name, it depicts sunrise in the harbor of Le Havre.
paintings.history: Painted in 1872, it was initially criticized but later became a landmark in a revolution in painting that rejected traditional styles.
paintings.symbolism: Quick brushstrokes and vibrant color reflect the fleeting nature of light and atmosphere.
